After an accident or near-miss has been identified, a team will discuss the events that led up to the incident and make recommendations to help prevent accidents from occurring in the future, according with the procedure  Incident Investigation. 

Any employee, including management, who is aware of a release, incident, or near miss involving the chlorine covered process, has the responsibility to report the incident to the Process Engineer or other applicable management personnel and the Incident Report Form must be completed. 

Hazards identified by employee suggestions are included in the hazardous situations definition and are treated according with the Incident Investigation procedure. Preventive and corrective actions identified and implemented are logged in the OHS Dashboard. 

9. Emergency Planning and Response 
5N Plus has a Level A trained first-response team, trained to a minimum of Hazardous materials technician level as per 29 CFR 1910.120(q)(6)(iii), in addition to Emergency Response Technician internal certification. In the event of an emergency or accidental release, an Emergency Response Program has been implemented and is available on site. The facility is required to have in place appropriate mechanisms for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response. 

The facility: 
- Does not store regulated flammable substances above a threshold quantity and is not required to coordinate response actions with local agencies; and 
- Has the appropriate mechanisms in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response. 
- Is included in the local community emergency response plan.

The GaCl3 production area has toxic gas detectors/alarms.  Entry to the facility is restricted by automatic locked doors. This helps ensure that contractors do not have unauthorized areas of the facility. 

7. Management of Change 
5N Plus has developed a procedure for management of change (PRO-1111-007 Change Control), this procedure is to evaluate and document temporary or permanent changes that may affect the use of a regulated substance in the current system. These changes include updates to equipment, system configuration, and operations of regulated processes and chemicals. 

Prior to the initiation of a change, it will be reviewed to determine the following [29 CFR 1910 §119(l)(2)(i)-(v)]: 
- The technical basis for the change; 
- The impact of the change on health and safety concerns; 
- Modifications that may be required to operating procedures; 
- The necessary time required to make the change; and 
- Authorization requirements for the proposed change. 

Once changes have been approved, relevant documents such as process safety information, facility diagrams, and operating, training, and maintenance procedures related to the covered process are reviewed and updated as necessary as part of the Management of Change process. These updates are logged and maintained in the form FOR-1111-007 Changes Control Follow-up.  
All employees and contractors involved in the regulated process will be notified of the change, and relevant training will be given if required. 

If the change is determined to be a significant change to the process, the PHA and Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) will be updated to reflect the change, as required by PSM/RMP regulations. 

8. Incident Investigation 
Incident investigation is a tool that enables the facility to document, track, and mitigate serious accidents and near misses.

2. Information Pertaining to Equipment in the Process
 
2.1 Relief System: The reactor system is equipped with one burst disk rated at 10 PSI and the confinement cabinets have 3 pressure relief valve set at 1/3 PSI. Also, all heating/cooling oil circuit have one pressure safety valve (15 PSI) to relief in a bucket the oil in case of overpressure. All relief systems are vent to the Wet Gas Scrubber. The chlorine containers are standard, vendor supplies containers which are exchanged when empty. 

2.2 Ventilation System: The facility utilizes one Fume Scrubbing System (scrubber). The Fume Scrubbing System utilizes a Model # VVS-48-FRP-7.0-180-S-1-F-460-3-60 packed bed, vertical counter-flow scrubbers to scrub fumes from six (6) reactors, one (1) chlorine distribution cabinet, and hood. The Fume Scrubbing units are designed to handle 7000 CFM of air flow.

2.3 Design Codes and Standards Employed: The GaCl3 Production components were designed and constructed in accordance with applicable codes and guidelines in place at the time of construction. The fume scrubbing equipment, vacuum system, and chlorine containers and cabinet were constructed and provided by external vendors. 2.4 Safety Systems 
Chlorine, Hydrochloric acid and Oxygen detectors/sensors are placed in strategic locations throughout the GaCl3 Production area. In the event of chlorine or Hydrochloric acid detection, an alarm is triggered at the facility (audible / visible on both levels), and the chlorine flow is stopped on the higher level. Also, in the event of a low or high concentration of Oxygen, an alarm is triggered at the facility (audible / visible on both levels), and the Nitrogen and Chlorine flow are stopped.

5N Plus Wisconsin Inc. has created and implemented a combined Process Safety Management and Risk Management Program (PSM/RMP) for their facility located at 6474, Blanchar's Crossing, DeForest, Wisconsin. This PSM/RMP Program was designed in accordance with the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration PSM Program (29 Code of Federal Regulations [CFR] 1910.119) and the USEPA Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) (40 CFR 68). 

A list of regulated chemicals and program applicability is provided below:

Process:                    Gallium Trichloride (GaCl3) Production
Substance:                  Chlorine	
CAS:                        7782-50-5	
Maximum Intended Inventory: 4000 lbs	
Applicability:              OSHA PSM and USEPA RMP
Program Level:              3
Covered System Components:
- Chlorine container management (Reception, handling, storage, shipment of used container)
- GaCl3 Process System Equipment and all utilities related to this process (Chlorine piping, Nitrogen piping, Cooling/heating unit, Wet gas scrubber, reactors and related instrumentation, Packaging and storage of final products)

1. Process Description

The gallium trichloride (GaCl3) process in place at the facility produces GaCl3 by reacting liquid gallium metal with chlorine within several reactors. The liquid gallium metal is placed in a reactor and heated.  Chlorine gas is introduced to the reactor and reacts with the gallium to form GaCl3. Nitrogen is used to purge the chlorine from the equipment. Once the reaction is complete the GaCl3 is then transferred to the container and cooled to form a solid.
 
The process consists of six reactors, one chlorine cabinet, a scrubber / ventilation system, and liquid nitrogen supply. The chlorine is stored within a dedicated room and the design complies with the NFPA400.  The main construction and safety point for the Chlorine room are:

- Gas room ho

moke.  Detectors are wired back to the PLC which will take action and put the system in stand-by mode for operator intervention
- All gas tubing containing chlorine is heat traced in order to ensure that chlorine does not condense and enter the reactor in liquid form causing serious safety issues
- All tubing carrying chlorine to the gas control panels is chlorine resistant metallic tubing
- The process room will be kept under negative atmosphere in order not to let and gas escape in case of an incident.  All air, gas, smoke must pass through our high efficiency scrubber before leaving the building.
- Gas levels inside the process room, oven room, chlorine storage room and plant can be monitored from a safe remote location.
- The control PLC is wired in such a way that control can be taken of the system/process from a remote safe location in case of problems.
- Data acquisition is present and records all the critical parameter of the reaction to be able to make some troubleshooting and correction in process or after.
- Chlorine room and cabinet design conform to the NFPA.
- Scrubber PLC interlock with the reactors in case of any failure of the scrubber the Chlorine injection is stop.
- Process room is design to be in negative pressure to ensure any release of chemical in the plant.
- Addition of E-Pro Electric Valve Closure Closure system upon installation of tonner, designed to automatically close valves on one-ton containers within 5 seconds after receiving an emergency signal.

This MIP applies to the GaCl3 Production process equipment listed in Table 10 [29 CFR 1910 §119(j)(1)(i)-(vi)]:

- Written Procedures/Inspections and Testing; 
- Records;

- E

quipment Deficiencies; and,

4. Operating Procedures Implementation Policy 
5N Plus maintains operating procedures which describe all employee tasks, data to be recorded, operating conditions to be maintained, and safety and health precautions to be utilized in operation of the GaCl3 Production process. The procedures are designed to be technically accurate and result in safe operation of the process. In addition, they are designed to be understandable to the employees and/or contractors. 5N Plus updates the operating procedures as changes are made to the process or to the operating limits of the process. 5N Plus annually reviews the operating procedures and certifies that they are current and accurate, as required by the PSM/RMP regulations. If the operating procedures are found to be out of date or inaccurate, necessary updates and revisions are made. 
The procedure Documents and records control (PRO-1111-001) includes the information about localisation and access to the SOP's. 

All phases of system operation are covered by the written procedures. Specifically, procedures are available for [29 CFR 1910 §119(f)(1)(i)(A)-(G)]: 
- Initial startup; 
- Normal operation; 
- Temporary operations as the need arises; 
- Emergency shutdown; 
- Normal shutdown; and, 
- Startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown. 

The procedures contain process operation limits, and provide information regarding the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct any deviations. Safety and health measures are included in the procedures to warn employees of potential risks and protective action(s) that should be taken [29 CFR 1910 §119(f)(1)(ii)-(iv)]. 

5. Training
5N Plus ensures that all employees involved with the GaCl3 Production processes at the facility, including maintenance and contractor employees, fully understand the health and safety hazards associated with chlorine and the product GaCl3.

This allows them to better protect themselves, fellow employees, and the neighboring community. In addition to the normal awareness training in place at the facility, which informs personnel of the hazards of chlorine and the safety precautions to use, training in operating procedures and practices, emergency response, and other required management controls are required for site personnel.
 
5N Plus identifies the personnel who require training, has developed a training procedure (PRO-1111-008) and plans and maintains a record of personnel training (FOR-1107-001 and training profile). The training program is regularly evaluated to ensure that it is providing appropriate information to the employees in a useful and understandable way. 

5N Plus's training program consists of three separate components: 
- Initial training [29 CFR 1910 §119(g)(1)]; 
- Refresher training [29 CFR 1910 §119(g)(2)]; and 
- Training documentation [29 CFR 1910 §119(g)(3)]. 

These components are consistent for training involving the following: 
- All Employees (hazard identification and emergency response); 
- Operators/Maintenance (operation and maintenance); 
- Contractors (hazard identification, emergency response, authority, accountability, responsibilities, and communication); and 
- Management (authority, accountability, responsibilities, and communication). 

Following the training by 5N Plus, employees will initial the training profile (PRG-1107-007) that states which section of training he/she has successfully completed and understood and refers those topics that are covered for that training section. [29 CFR 1910 §119(g)(3)]. This form is also initialling by the person responsible of the training to state the section has been covered and understood by the employee.
All employees receive hazard identification and emergency evacuation training upon hire. The remainder of this document focuses on personnel directly involved with operating and/or maintaining the GaCl3 P

roduction processes at the facility. More detailed training specific to the GaCl3 Production processes is provided for Operators and Maintenance personnel. 

6. Contractors:
5N Plus will conduct a screening process for work conducted by outside contract workers to help ensure that contractors carry out the job tasks in a safe and appropriate manner. 
Contract labor performing maintenance, renovation, or other work on or adjacent to a regulated process is covered under this section of the PSM/RMP regulations. It does not apply to contractors providing other services which do not influence process safety. Such services include custodial work, food and drink services, and laundry or other supply services. 
5N Plus will evaluate the contract employer's safety performance and programs as well as their knowledge, experience, and certifications (Contractor's compliance Form). The contractor's work and experience will be periodically evaluated [29 CFR 1910 §119(h)(2)].  

Contract employers will be informed of the known potential fire, explosion, and/or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work in the process [29 CFR 1910 §119(h)(2(ii)]. The contract employer will assure that each contract employee is instructed in the potential fire, explosion, and/or toxic release hazards related to his or her work in the process area. The contract employer is required to train their employees and assure that each contract employee is trained in work practices to a level adequate to safely perform their job [29 CFR 1910 §119(h)(3)]. 5N Plus will also inform contractor employers of any applicable safety rules at the facility (EHS Rules-Contractors Form).  The contract employer will assure that all contract employees are aware of the applicable provisions of the facility's Emergency Action Plan [29 CFR 1910 §119(h)(2)(iii)].
